doc/requirements.txt.message: Does this need to be here? I am curious on the why...

I forgot to share the link.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-ui/src/branch/master/tox.ini#L9

The basic reason is to generate the "Source Code Index".

At the moment, this is unnecessary as modules in requirements.txt are installed when ironic-ui is installed in a venv. However, this works just because ironic-ui specifes "install_command" with upper-constraints.txt [1] and this is not the way used in most OpenStack projects. Once install_command was dropped and the upper-constraints is specified in "deps", horizon from Ussuri release would be installed as upper-constraints.txt is not specified when installing ironic-ui into a tox venv. In such case, the solution would be either to add -rrequirements.txt to "deps" or to have horizon in doc/requirements.txt (as we do now). 

I am not a maintainer of ironic-ui, so I have no strong opinion on this. What is the preference from the ironic-ui maintainer? Ideally I think it is better to sync the best practice in OpenStack dev community.
IMHO it is better to follow the convention used widely in the OpenStack community. I modified tox.ini and doc/requirements.txt in the next patch set.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: I guess this could subtly change the race conditions we have to deal with.

The main race that triggered my recent patch chain goes like this:

* host1 gets nodes from DB, including an orphan
* host2 takes over node in RT (sets node.host)
* host1 deletes "orphan" which now belongs to host2

I think in that case the race could still happen, this just changes the timing a little.

As in what the driver reports vs what compute nodes are in the DB? For what _get_compute_nodes_in_db is using that shouldn't matter. nodenames are just used as a single if the driver is managing any nodes. Without these calls being swapped, even if there are compute nodes in the DB, if we get VirtDriverNotReady we return but if we don't get VirtDriverNotReady then we still process the nodenames and compute nodes below looking for orphans and such.
An alternative that would allow keeping the order the same is to emit the warn/error in the calling method if we get an empty list back.

I started to reply here but it turned into a novel. I'll add a comment on the use cases for where the encryption secret should come from.

Update:
- Boot request comes in with "give me an encrypted vTPM of $type and $version" (no secret information)
- Nova [1] randomly generates a passphrase and uploads it to the key manager. The key manager responds with a $secret_uuid.
- Nova saves that $secret_uuid in the instance's system_metadata.
- Nova creates a libvirt secret with name=$instance_uuid [2], UUID=$secret_uuid, usage type='vtpm', ephemeral='yes' [3], and private='yes' [4], and sets its value to the generated passphrase. This step must be done once per instance per libvirtd process to get that secret loaded into memory. (Will need an ensure_vtpm_secret type of routine to do this only if not already done, to save on barbican traffic etc.)
- Nova adds the relevant chunk to the instance's domain XML, containing $type, $version, and $secret_uuid and boots the VM. The vTPM appears in the VM as /dev/tpm0 and "just works" (no additional unlocking is required from within).
- Once the guest boots, nova deletes (undefines) the secret.
- When an instance is deleted, nova deletes the secret from the key manager.

[1] This part could theoretically be done at the conductor, but since compute will need the secret anyway, we might as well do it all at compute.
[2] Names are internal to the secret XML, but must be unique per libvirtd.
[3] ephemeral ensures the secret never gets stored on disk
[4] private means you can't dump the secret from virsh

Had some discussion with jroll today, which I still need to digest [1].

Summary of the flow we discussed:
- Boot request comes in with "give me an encrypted vTPM" (no specifics).
- Nova creates a brand new libvirty secret per [2] using... random data? and grabs its $secret_uuid
- Nova goes out to $configured_keymanager via castellan and creates a key there with $secret_uuid.
- Nova boots the instance with the relevant XML

      <tpm model='tpm-tis'>
        <backend type='emulator' version='2.0'>
          <encryption secret='$secret_uuid'/>
        </backend>
      </tpm>

- The VM user logs into the VM, sees a virginal TPM, and bootstraps it with whatever kind of secret satisfies the user's need.

Shelve, offload, unshelve will result in an instance with an empty TPM right? That's a problem for any real user of this.

Yeah, that's a problem. I'm open to suggestions. The ones that come to mind aren't lovely:

- Store the data within the snapshot. Would have to find a way to get it there, and also a way to peel it back out afterward. Booting the snapshot on a host that doesn't know how to do the latter could result in the guts of your VM being able to see that file. It's encrypted, so that's maybe not a show-stopper, but it's still very icky.
- Store the data file in the instance record itself. This would work for all the lifecycle operations (as opposed to putting it in the instance dir). The thing ought to be pretty small (my test ones are just over 4KB, though I haven't really exercised them much) but that doesn't seem like the kind of thing we want to pollute the db with.
- Similarly the snapshot metadata.
- Create a separate glance image for the file. Associate the two via metadata. Pull it down and unpack it during unshelve (and un-everything-else).
- Don't natively support these operations; require admin/orchestrator to save/restore the file.

BTW, not sure I agree that "any real user" relies on the shelve-offload operation. In particular, I think the use case that's driving this work relies on the VM with the vTPM being alive all the time, so I wouldn't expect they would ever want to offload it. But I'll ask.

> That's because shelve-offload doesn't preserve the local instance
 > directory?

Yeah, so jroll and I discussed a way to tweak the spec that would remove this ick, and simplify some other things as well. TL;DR: the vTPM sticks exclusively with the instance, not with the image. So all and only operations that have an instance associated with them to start with will keep the vTPM data associated with the original instance:
- Unshelve
- Rebuild (any TPM meta on the new image is ignored, though I reckon we should error if the version/model conflict with the existing)
- Resize / migrate (as noted below) including cross-cell
- Rescue (this one shouldn't need to go to swift)

Whereas any operations that don't start off with an instance will either get a fresh new vTPM (if requested via the flavor/image as usual) or none at all. That may just be Spawn (from a snapshot of an instance that had a vTPM).

...and Evacuate is still simply busted, sorry.

In addition to allowing us to delete secrets again, this also removes the need to ever store the secret UUID or swift obj info in the image meta. And it eliminates the question of having "cloned" the same vTPM by spawning multiple instances from the same image.

This seems like a crisp enough line that, if well documented, it should be sensible and acceptable to users.

nts: There was concern that this could end you up with multiple swift objects per instance, but like the snapshot resulting from shelve or backup, it is either always new or supersedes the previous. We simply don't create the swift obj for the createImage action, because there's no operation where we would use it. Rebuild doesn't rely on a prior backup because it's happening on the original host where the data file still resides.

The configuration should use

 [key_manager]
 auth_type = token

When nova calls a castellan API, it'll pass the result of credential_factory(CONF, context) [1], which will be the context.auth_token, as the `context` param. The backend uses that to create a ksa Session (e.g. [2] for the barbican backend) and uses that Session to talk to the service.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/castellan/src/branch/master/castellan/common/utils.py#L95
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/castellan/src/branch/master/castellan/key_manager/barbican_key_manager.py#L124-L126

The keymgr determines the ownership of the key based on the RequestContext when the instance is created. Any time the key needs to be accessed subsequently, the keymgr service needs to be convinced that *that* RequestContext is allowed to do so. How all of that works is (and should remain) a total black box to me (and to nova).

/COMMIT_MSG.message: preserve num_instances during update_available_resource

During the execution of the update_available_resource perodic task the num_instances value is reset and saved to the db while the task is running. As a result the NumInstancesFilter can allow hosts to pass that would otherwise be rejected due to the incorrect data. This change preserves the number of instances running on the host while the periodic task completes.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: In the case where there is a reboot required config and the host-lock/host-unlock (reboot) is skipped - it appears that this change will still clear the alarm even though a reboot is still required?
Since its a reboot-required config, then the alarm will be cleared on the host-lock/host-unlock.  i.e. a runtime manifest apply is not sufficient to clear the alarm

/etc/platform/.config_applied is updated by puppet at:
puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/config.pp
which occurs on the manifest apply following a host-lock/unlock.  A reboot-required config_uuid must ensure a reboot has occured.

Hi John
Thanks. if so , do you think clear the config_target when node is starting is good idea?

But config_target will keep the last boot cycle value , not be changed by puppet ? is it ? 

Do you have any suggestion to fix this is issue ?
Ok. in this case , how will this alarm is cleared ?

This approach has a window whereby the config could be updated as reboot required and never applied over a reboot.  i.e. after host-unlock but before first_applied_config is set another reboot required config. (e.g.for example an ntp-modify)

This solution adds overhead of another RPC call for every reboot required operation; a better solution would be track whether the first_reboot_flag has been set already for that host; and have the agent send that information in when updating inventory to the conductor.

Please consider a solution which will not miss a configuration needed to be applied.  One potential solution is to have the sysinv-conductor track a list to be applied UUIDs per host to determine whether the alarm could be cleared (i.e. if the reboot required flag has already been satisfied if reboot required has been applied and subsequent UUID are noreboot required)  It can clear this per host list whenever the alarm is cleared.

> This approach has a window whereby the config could be updated as
 > reboot required and never applied over a reboot.  i.e. after
 > host-unlock but before first_applied_config is set another reboot
 > required config. (e.g.for example an ntp-modify)
 > 
[Austin] if reboot flag is explicitly, I don't think
it will be impacted. only one situation: first_applied_config is not set yet, then config_target is a reboot explicitly needed, and then another config request is coming. 
the best solution I think is that it won't allow user config before refport_applied_config is set. it will shortly impact the system operation during boot, but it will be more safety.

 > This solution adds overhead of another RPC call for every reboot
 > required operation; a better solution would be track whether the

specs/ussuri/approved/provider-config-fi.message: Okay, so this means when we document for ironic we need to make it clear that they should make sure their "generic" entry sorts last.
Will we continue to support name for identification?
Yes, of all the options proposed this will actually be the easiest to implement since it is already done.

All except for that very last part.

$COMPUTE_NODE exists for two purposes:
- to allow you to set up your configuration before the provider name/uuid is known;
- to allow you to set defaults for any compute nodes not specified explicitly.

The latter only applies to ironic. And ironic is also the only case where a node can "appear" at runtime. So in that case, we first look for it by name/uuid (which for ironic are the same) and if not found, use $COMPUTE_NODE.

The only scenario where we ignore+log is when a provider appears whose explicit name and uuid both exist in the config. And that can only happen for nested providers, never for compute nodes (ironic or otherwise).

Just to reiterate, before init, you will be checking for uuid/name duplicates and failing the service.

After init, uuid/name takes precedence over $COMPUTE_NODE, but duplicates within uuid/name or cases with only $COMPUTE_NODE resolving to same uuid is repeated, you would ignore the rps and log a warning.
After init, If $COMPUTE_NODE resolves to the same UUID, should we be skipping both the rps or following the precedence rule?

Both options were discussed, but allowing entries with explicit uuid/name take precedence over $COMPUTE_NODE allows us to avoid running into unresolvable conflicts in periodic updates in a simpler manner.

I suggest changing this to 3.1.0 (or higher) and add

  ignore_basepython_conflict = true

(see the current cinder tox.ini).  Otherwise, with basepython set as python3 in the [testenv] at line 8, the basepython overrides the "inferred" environments when you run 'tox -epy36' or 'tox -epy37', and the virtualenv for those tests will use whatever the system py3 is instead of honoring one requested by the user.  (Also, you won't need to declare a basepython at line 62, the correct one will be inferred from the -py27 suffix.)

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: The changes you have made in this file should be done in a new lmon.pp manifest file instead.

This could all be done within the ERB file, rather than a series of file_line resources. For example, the ERB file can have something like:

<%- if @management_interface -%>
management_interface=<%= @management_interface %>
<%- else -%>
management_interface=
<%- end -%>

This way, the entire file is updated at once, and only if it needs to be modified. With the current implementation, puppet is generating or updating the file with a template full of empty settings, then updating each setting, and could be needlessly updating the file on every puppet apply.
As Don indicated in an earlier comment, this should be done within the erb file itself.

Can we probably generalize it, so that any asynchronous deploy step can be checked for success? I.e. if a deploy step returns DEPLOYWAIT, then before moving to another steps conductor calls the corresponding interface's check_step_status that either returns DEPLOYWAIT (still busy), None (done) or raises.

There are a few ways we could tackle this one.

We could make continue_deploy set skip_current_deploy_step: false, and do the polling there. We'd need some logic to send the command on the first call.

Or we could make this an in-band deploy step, and have the polling handled in the normal way. I was a bit concerned about backwards compatibility between ironic and IPA with this though - we'd need a ramdisk that supports in-band deploy steps.
Possibly. IPA API version might be the best thing to check here. It would be nice to keep the polling in one place (after deprecation period is over).
Thinking more about it, I think this is an important extension point (think custom kernel params, modifying files, etc). Maybe split "prepare_boot" and "reboot_to_instance"?
None? We shouldn't do anything on a tenant network, we probably won't have access to it at all.
Should we maybe split further at this point? To accommodate deploy steps that have to be done on a deployed but powered off machine?
Certainly possible. What network should the node be on at the time?

I wonder if we should separate the 'prepare()' (or parts of the prepare()) from the deploy step, but maybe that will become clearer while splitting this up. And I think we can prob do that later too, since the priority of these would be > 100. So forget I brought this up.
For automated cleaning, when there is a version mismatch, we restart the cleaning. Why not restart the deployment?

In general we don't restart deployments for any reason currently. Cleaning failure requires operator intervention, deployment does not. Maybe it's something we should consider. In general though we might prefer allowing a higher layer (nova) to perform a retry.

Lets see how it goes. We can always add a restart feature later (configurable of course!)

I'm not sure how nova would know whether it would be ok to retry or not, given it is an IPA version mismatch...? Anyway, something to think about/future.

specs/stein/new_docs.rst.message: I don't fully agree. Strictly speaking, refactoring is not really applicable for improving documentation. It's supposed to lead to an equal result (if applied to code). Restructuring is a better term here, IMO, and I don't see any issues in restructuring the existing documentation step by step. However, I totally agree that we need to see what should be the eventual result, at least its main criterias. The form may be different after different iterations, that's fine. We can come to something now, but when we get it, we'll start using it and have more ideas of how to improve it. There's no such thing as "done" here.
I'd prefer to create this structure with hands. Consciously, thinking about why it should be like this, and not that.
Not sure if it's true. Incomplete? Yes. But as far as outdated, I would like to know what exactly is outdated. Usually if we find something that's outdated we fix it asap.
